Description: Lower body fragment of East Greek black-figured pottery vessel, slipped on exterior. Lion to left, its right forepaw raised (preserved the forepart of the lion except the upper part of its head); in the field, blob rosettes; possible added red on its neck, shoulder, and left foreleg; to the left of the lion broad black area, with vertical incisions, alternate sections in added red; most added red has flaked, removing the glaze below as well.
Curator's comments: Object owned and held by the Greco-Roman Museum, Alexandria. This record is included in the British Museum database as part of the Museum’s Naukratis Project, a research collaboration that aims to virtually re-unite finds from the ancient port city of Naukratis, now distributed over 80 museums worldwide.
The object to the left does not seem to be drapery, belonging to a potnia theron, and is rather too simple to be architectural, e.g. a fountain.
Bibliographic references: Venit 1988 / Greek Painted Pottery from Naukratis in Egyptian Museums (p. 11, no. 33 pl. 8)
Villing et al 2013-2015 / Naukratis: Greeks in Egypt (GG.910)
